content:
Method 2 is a great way to keep all your vehicles in one place, and it's easy to manage and filter the data.

Here's a sample layout to get you started:

| Date | Vehicle | Description | Cost | Mileage | Category |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 2022-02-15 | 2018 Toyota Corolla | Oil change and tire rotation | 35.00 | 25,000 | Maintenance |
| 2022-03-01 | 2015 Honda Civic | Faulty oxygen sensor replacement and brake pad replacement | 250.00 | 60,500 | Repairs |
| 2022-04-10 | 2020 Honda Odyssey | Scheduled maintenance (30,000 miles) | 120.00 | 30,500 | Maintenance |
| 2022-05-15 | 2007 Yamaha FZ6 | Chain cleaning and lubrication | 20.00 | 35,000 | Maintenance |

You can add more columns or rows as needed, and use filters to quickly view maintenance history for a specific vehicle. For example, you can filter the "Vehicle" column to show only the 2018 Toyota Corolla's maintenance history.

Some tips to keep in mind:

* Be consistent with your vehicle names (e.g., always use "2018 Toyota Corolla" instead of "Toyota Corolla" or "Corolla").
* Use a standard format for the "Description" column (e.g., "Oil change and tire rotation" instead of "oil change, tire rotation").
* Consider using a separate column for the type of maintenance or repair (e.g., "Scheduled", "Unscheduled", "Repair", "Inspection").
* You can use formulas to calculate total costs per vehicle, average cost per mile, or other metrics that are important to you.

Remember to update your spreadsheet regularly, and review it periodically to identify trends, patterns, and areas for improvement. This will help you stay on top of your vehicle maintenance costs and make informed decisions about your vehicles' care.
